title: 115_hr2740
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rabbi Michoel Ber Weissmandl Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2017". Rabbi Michoel Ber Weissmandl, born in Hungary in 1903, played a key role in saving Slovakian Jews during the Holocaust by establishing an underground organization to negotiate with officials. He also obtained visas to protect Jewish people in Europe and raised awareness through telegrams. Weissmandl established a Working Group with a diverse membership to save people from the Holocaust, documented Auschwitz Escapees' accounts in the "Auschwitz Protocols", and made appeals for action. Rabbi Weissmandl played a key role in disrupting the Holocaust by appealing for the use of Allied air resources. He also informed the Working Group about the true nature of deportations in Slovakia and was instrumental in the Kindertransport rescue. Upon coming to America in 1945, he established the first Yeshiva campus in Mount Kisco, New York, for Holocaust survivors. Rabbi Weissmandl's influence has been significant in the Talmudic scholar communities in Brooklyn, New York, and across the United States. Rabbi Weissmandl's influence has been significant in the Talmudic scholar communities in Brooklyn, New York, and across the United States. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. The Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be presented to Rabbi Michoel Ber Weissmandl for his valor during World War II. The Weissmandl Committee may accept the medal on his behalf, and the Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Following the presentation of the gold medal in honor of Michoel Ber Weissmandl, the medal will be given to Samuel Dovid Weissmandl or Rabbi Menachem Meir Weissmandl if he is not present. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze at a price covering costs. The gold medal is considered a national medal and all medals struck under this Act are considered numismatic items.
